message: Happy New Year! Wishing you and your loved ones all the best in 2017.

Today marks the first day of the 115th Congress. I look forward to continuing my work to make our San Joaquin Valley a better place and improve opportunities for you, the people of the Valley. Below is a link to a comprehensive overview of some of the highlights of what my colleagues and I accomplished over the past two years for the Valley, California, and our entire nation.   As Congress begins the 115th Congress, I will continue my efforts to: - improve water reliability, security and quality for all   Californians; - advocate for increased investment in our nation’s transportation and infrastructure systems; - work to fix a broken immigration system to make it more reliable and fair; - reform our tax system to make it less complex and ensure that everyone pays their fair share; - and reform entitlement programs, like Social Security and Medicare, in a responsible way, so we can protect the promise made to those currently dependent on these programs and ensure their long-term solvency for future generations.  Thank you for allowing me the opportunity to serve you in our nation’s capital. Please contact my Fresno, Merced, or Washington, D.C. offices, if we can ever be of assistance.

I applaud the House passage of the Taxpayers' Right to Know Act. This bipartisan legislation would save tax payer dollars and eliminate government waste within federal agencies. Today, the national debt is approaching $20 trillion dollars, which is approximately $61,350 per U.S. citizen, and ensuring a robust 21st century U.S. economy will require Congress to get our fiscal house in order. As a co-chair of the Blue Dog Coalition, I will continue supporting fiscally sustainable policies that will grow our Valley and U.S. economy.

Finally, the Valley is getting much needed rain in the Valley and snow in the mountains. However, capturing that water is directly reliant upon our ability to create additional water storage, like building Temperance Flat Dam, which I have long supported. Most recent scientific reports indicate that temperatures are rising, creating a decline in the snow pack that we have historically relied upon as natural water storage.  As a result, runoff will increase during the fall and winter months, requiring us to increase California’s water storage to ensure that farmers, farm workers, and farming communities are equipped with an adequate water supply in future dry years. This morning, the San Joaquin Valley Water Infrastructure Authority is holding a press conference to call attention to this very important matter.

My heart is broken for the family of Master Sgt. Debra Clayton and the people of Florida. This morning, Master Sgt. Clayton was shot and killed, and an Orange County Sheriff Deputy was killed in a car accident while searching for the suspect.   These horrific tragedies happened to take place on #NationalLawEnforcementAppreciationDay. Now, more than ever, we must come together as a nation to show our support and appreciation for our law enforcement officers. That means thanking law enforcement for keeping our communities safe, and it also means being vigilant and reporting crimes if we witness something that is wrong.   Today and every day, my thoughts and prayers are with the men and women in blue, especially with the loved ones of Master Sgt. Debra Clayton and the Orange County Sheriff Deputy.
As parts of the county continue to experience flood conditions, I encourage all Madera County residents to sign up for the Madera County Emergency Warning System.

The House just passed the HALOS Act, bipartisan legislation that would eliminate unnecessary and burdensome regulations and would open more pathways for #startups to seek investment opportunities. As the nation’s leaders in #innovation and #technology, startups have an important role in the U.S. economy, and ensuring that they have the necessary capital to continue generating new ideas is crucial to the success of the industry.

After over five years of record breaking drought conditions, we welcome the above-average rain and snow, and also hope that it does not cause destructive flooding. Regrettably, to reduce potential flooding, water is being released out to the ocean. That precious water could be used to replenish groundwater aquifers that were depleted during the drought or could be carried over in above ground storage for use in dry years. That water could help ensure that our farming communities will not continue to deal with double digit unemployment numbers.   The WIIN Act, which was enacted in December, provides funding for water storage and groundwater banking projects. It is my sincere hope that both surface storage and groundwater recharge projects, like raising the gates at New Exchequer Dam, and building Sites Reservoir and Temperance Flat Dam, and others, like the Los Banos Creek Reservoir and raising San Luis Reservoir, are advanced as rapidly as possible, so we can begin to capture the much-needed water that comes from these storms. Fixing California’s broken water system requires a multi-pronged approach, and focusing on how we improve our water infrastructure and storage capacity will be imperative as we work to update California’s water system so it can meet the growing demands of the 21st century. #CAstorm #CAflood
Proud of the residents in Planada who came together to paint these beautiful murals and are helping to make the community a better place.

The rain from recent storms is welcomed by all of us in the San Joaquin Valley. The WIIN Act, enacted into law in December, provides funding for CA water storage projects, so we can capture more water during storm events for the dry years.

Today, our nation celebrates the life of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. I will be joining San Joaquin Valley residents at community events in Fresno and Merced to recognize the great service and sacrifice of Dr. King. Our nation is a better place because of Dr. King’s commitment to ensuring equality for all.
It was great to see many of you yesterday as we celebrated the life of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Dr. King will always remain to be an inspiration to all of us. #MLKDAY

Looking forward to welcoming the Merced County Sheriff's Posse to our nation's capital. It is an honor for Merced County to have been chosen to be part of the inaugural parade, a tradition that celebrates America's democracy. #Inauguration2017
It's been absolutely wonderful visiting with constituents who are here for tomorrow's inauguration and to celebrate our country's great democracy! #Inauguration2017

The peaceful transition of power is fundamental to America’s Democratic principles.  As an elected member of the Legislative Branch, a co-equal branch of government, I believe it is my role and responsibility to attend the President’s swearing-in ceremony.   Congress must focus on governing, not on harmful partisan rhetoric. We are Americans first, not Democrats or Republicans. I remain committed to finding areas of compromise by working on a bipartisan basis with my colleagues in Congress and the Trump Administration because it’s the only way we can solve problems and heal our divided nation. #Inauguration2017

On Saturday, I had the pleasure of taking the Merced Sheriff’s Posse on a tour of the U.S. Capitol Building, and we had the opportunity to go on the grounds of where the swearing-in of the President took place. It was an honor to have Sheriff Vern Warnke, the Sheriff’s Posse and their families in Washington, D.C. to participate in a historical moment for our nation.

There are nearly 750,000 young people receiving deportation protections and work authorization under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. These hard working young men and women live in our San Joaquin Valley, and they add so much value to Valley communities and our entire nation. #saveDACA #DACA

It's always great to be on KMPH FOX 26's Great Day with Kim and Kopi! I talked about the need for Congress to work together and the importance of making investments in our Valley's & nation's infrastructure.

Building a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border is not a real solution to fixing our broken immigration system. This afternoon, President Trump expressed support for a 20 percent tax on imports from Mexico to pay for the wall. If implemented, a 20 percent import tax on Mexican goods would accelerate a trade war between the United States and Mexico. We saw similar effects of these types of trade wars most recently during the U.S.-Mexico trucking dispute, which took place for seven years between 2009-2015, when Mexico legally imposed retaliatory tariffs on U.S. exports. The California agriculture industry bore the brunt of those retaliatory tariffs. If President Trump and Republicans in Congress move forward with putting a 20 percent tax on Mexican imports, then California products are likely to be immediately impacted.   In addition to the economic effects of building a wall and imposing a tax on Mexican goods, immigrant children and their families are fearful of being deported. President Trump’s executive order only further divides our country and raises alarm among immigrant families.  Click the link below to read my entire statement on President Trump's executive order to build a wall.

It's an honor to welcome Armenian Ambassador to the United States, Grigor Hovhannissian, to California's San Joaquin Valley. Today, I joined Ambassador Hovhannissian, President Castro, and Honorary Consul Apkarian at the Armenian Genocide Monument at Fresno State. We will never forget the tragedy of the Armenian genocide and the 1.5 million lives lost.

President Trump's executive order is affecting a family in my Congressional district. My number one priority is Americans' safety both at home and abroad, but it is not the American way to ban individuals, mostly women and children, who have gone through an extensive vetting process to enter the United States and are fleeing war-torn regions of the world.

Due to President Trump’s hasty decision making, a 12-year-old girl with parents who are U.S. citizens and Los Banos residents is banned from entering the United States. My office is doing everything within our jurisdiction to help Mr. Ali and his daughter to get home as soon as possible and safely.  As a member of Congress, my number one priority is Americans’ safety both at home and abroad, and I think it’s obvious that keeping a 12-year-old out of the country is not strengthening the safety of our nation. This executive order is having a devastating impact on hundreds of other individuals and immigrant families that thought the United States would be helping them seek refuge. The vast majority of individuals being detained or prohibited from entering the United States have already been through one of the most extensive vetting processes in the world.  Clearly, President Trump’s executive order was not vetted thoroughly by his Administration. Not only is it flawed policy, but it has the potential to be ruled unconstitutional.   Let us never forget that America’s diversity is what makes us strong. Banning individuals, mostly women and children, from entering the United States is not the American way. I will be supporting legislation that will rescind President Trump’s executive order because the executive order is flawed and is not making the American people safer.

America is a nation of immigrants past and present, and the Ali family is a reflection of America. Mr. Ahmed Ali and his family are not only constituents of mine, but they are U.S. citizens who need our country’s help. Mr. Ali and his wife earned their U.S. citizenship and for seven years, the Ali family has gone through a rigorous vetting process to bring their 12-year-old daughter home to the United States. Their daughter has been legally granted a U.S. immigrant visa to come to the country and become a United States citizen. President Trump’s executive order is preventing this legal process from taking place, and is putting Mr. Ali and his young daughter in harm’s way while they wait in Djibouti. Sadly, there are many others that are facing similar circumstances. It is my intent as their Congressman to explore every appropriate option to get them back to the United States safely.

President Trump’s executive order is putting Ahmed Ali and his daughter, Eman, in harm’s way as they wait in Djibouti. Eman is a 12-year-old girl with parents who are both American citizens. After six years of extreme vetting, Eman received a U.S. immigrant visa. Clearly, she is not a threat to our country, and I urge the President and Secretary John Kelly to let Eman join her American family in the United States.

Congressman Ted Poe and I introduced legislation to protect the Crime Victims Fund. Ensuring that the non-taxer money in the Fund is used only for its intended purposes is one of my highest priorities in Congress, and this bill meets that goal. As co-chairs of the Congressional Victims’ Rights Caucus, Congressman Poe and I support and advocate for all victims and survivors of crime. Unfortunately, there are many children, women, and men who do not have access to the services they need to heal. The Victims’ Rights Caucus will be working diligently in the 115th Congress to protect the money in the Fund, so victim service providers can expand assistance to those individuals who sadly have been victims of crime.

I am thrilled to know that Eman and her father are on their way home and hours from being reunited with their family. Eman, a 12 year-old-girl with U.S. citizen parents, was stuck in Djibouti with her father, in harms way for one week, because of President Trump’s flawed executive order. Banning the travel of individuals, like Eman, who have gone through a rigorous vetting process from entering the United States is not the American way and could be ruled unconstitutional. U.S. District Court Judge Robart’s ruling to temporarily suspend the executive order gives the Administration and Congress an opportunity to fully assess the executive order and its impacts on American citizens, legal permanent residents, and refugees. Since September 11, 2001, there has been a strong bipartisan consensus to implement policies to keep Americans safe, and part of that effort includes a long and rigorous process to obtain an immigrant visa. In Eman’s case, she went through six years of thorough vetting. It is my first constitutional duty to ensure American safety, and clearly, Eman is not a dangerous threat to our country. A revised executive order must not conflict with protections under the United States constitution.

Welcome home, Eman!   I join with the Ali family, the Los Banos community, and people throughout the nation in welcoming Eman and her father home. It's been a long journey for Eman, and I wish her the very best as she spends time with her family and settles into being home.
Yesterday, I had the opportunity to meet with folks with the California Farm Bureau Federation and took them on an impromptu tour of our nation's Capitol.

In order to maintain and grow our San Joaquin Valley economy, we must have a secure water supply and a thriving agriculture industry. As a member of both the House Agriculture and Natural Resources Committees, I have the distinct opportunity to advocate for many policies that impact our Valley, like working to ensure a reliable water supply and supporting the San Joaquin Valley farmers who produce the highest quality food and fiber for the world. Additionally, I will be a leader in negotiating the 2018 Farm Bill, which will not only have a direct effect on farming, ranching, and dairy operations, but also on funding for nutrition assistance, conservation, and rural development programs.

Today’s tour made it evident that declaring a flood emergency for Merced County is absolutely necessary. I commend the efforts of Sheriff Warnke and the county Office of Emergency Services for their due diligence in bringing together all levels of government to address the flood impacts throughout Merced County. Clearly, this is an all hands on deck effort, and we are using every tool available to keep residents safe and reduce potential flood damage.

It was very special to meet Eman and see her reunited with her family. The outpouring of support that the Ali family has received from the Los Banos community has been both remarkable and inspirational.

For years I've advocated and worked hard to give California dairy producers the opportunity to join the Federal Milk Marketing Order. Finally, the United States Department of Agriculture released a proposal that would allow California's dairy producers to make their own determination of what is best for California’s dairy industry. I will continue working with California’s dairymen and cooperatives as they assess the USDA proposal and decide on the merits of remaining independent or joining the 10 other Federal Milk Marketing Orders around the country.#CADairy

On Friday, I had the opportunity to meet with Ethan Torres, the first student at El Capitan High School Merced, California to ever receive a congressional nomination to a military academy. Ethan was nominated to attend the U.S. Air Force Academy. The young men and women who receive a congressional nomination to attend our nation’s military academies are well-rounded, bright, and committed, and Ethan is no exception. I’m confident that Ethan has a great future ahead of him. I commend Principal Shaw and his faculty and staff for always striving to ensure that their students are well-educated and prepared for the future.

My thoughts are with the people in Butte, Sutter, and Yuba counties. To prevent further flood damage in California, I joined Congressman John Garamendi and my California colleagues in sending a letter to President Trump to request a Major Disaster declaration under the Stafford Act. A Major Disaster declaration will provide greater collaboration among local, state, and federal governments and will provide immediate resources where they are needed.  We must invest in California’s water infrastructure. We need additional water storage in order to prevent devastating flood conditions and increase our sustainability to drought. These two things go hand in hand. There is another series of storms expected later this week, and we must use every tool available to reduce potential flood damage and accidents.

This week, I spoke on the House floor to honor the life of a loving family man, great friend, veteran, civil rights leader, and former Fresno City Councilman, Mr. Joe Williams. No matter who you were or how well Joe knew you, best friend or stranger, Joe had a way of making everyone feel important and special.  He will be remembered for the selfless way in which he lived his life, always looking to help those in the community who were in need. I join his family in honoring his life, love for his community and service to his country. Joe, you are greatly missed.
As we experience more storms and flooding in Merced, please do what you can to stay safe. Go to www.countyofmerced.com/alert to sign up for Merced County emergency alerts.

It's been 75 years since February 19, 1942, the day when President Franklin Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066.  Following Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor in World War II, 120,000 individuals of Japanese descent were forced to leave their homes and were ordered into prison camps. Japanese Americans, including thousands from our Central Valley, had their civil rights and human rights completely violated by the U.S. government. It was a very sad and dark time in our nation's history. I have deep respect and gratitude for the Japanese Americans in our Valley and throughout the nation who tell their stories and their family's stories because we must never forget!

During #BlackHistoryMonth, we recognize the accomplishments and contributions of African Americans throughout U.S. History. I thought it was fitting and appropriate to take the opportunity to honor the life of Henry Lemay. Henry was a proud veteran, man of faith, and good friend to many of us. #BHM2017

Please join me in celebrating #EngineersWeek. Through outreach and engagement, we can get young people, especially young women, excited about an education and career path in engineering. Let's work together to ensure that the United States continues to be the world leader in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) education.

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to meet with UC Merced students. We talked about important federal policies, like immigration and the need to protect DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) recipients. Keep up the great work, Bobcats!

The rain is letting up but efforts to address the flooding in Merced County are still in full force. Today, I joined Merced County Sheriff Warnke on a helicopter tour to see current flood conditions in Merced County. #CAStorm #CAFlood
ICYMI: I was on Sunday Morning Matters with Evan Onstot. We covered a lot of topics, including water infrastructure and foreign policy.

Today, the Agriculture Subcommittee on Livestock and Foreign Agriculture held its first hearing on the next Farm Bill to talk specifically about international market development programs, which are vital for ensuring that American agriculture exporters have opportunities to sell their goods in other countries. The Market Access Program (MAP), Foreign Market Development Program (FMD), and Technical Assistance for Specialty Crops (TASC) make it easier for America’s farmers, ranchers, and dairy producers to market their products in foreign markets that are increasingly calling for more of the highest quality food and fiber produced by the United States. The American agriculture industry is the best in the world and through the next Farm Bill, we can help ensure that America’s farmers, ranchers, and dairy producers are given the necessary tools for success in the international marketplace.

With the announcement of today’s water allocations, I share in both the relief and the frustration of many farmers and Central Valley residents. Had water infrastructure projects, like Temperance Flat Dam and Sites Reservoir, been built prior to this record rainfall, then more water would be stored for years with less precipitation and snowfall, to be made available to respond to future human and ecosystem needs. Congress and the Administration must work together on a bipartisan basis to make desperately needed investments in California’s water infrastructure, so that years from now, God willing, when there is another record breaking wet year, there will be the storage capacity to capture water from the rain and snow.

As we start off Women’s History Month, I want to take this opportunity to recognize my mom, Lena Costa, and all the women who grew up during the women’s suffrage movement. Mom was only five years old when women earned the right to vote, and like many other young girls and women, mom quickly learned the importance of education and the power of knowledge. Lena Costa made a difference, and she wanted my sister and me to have opportunities that she never had. Because of our mother’s passion to ensure that her children could achieve the American Dream, my sister created a scholarship in our mother’s name at San Joaquin Memorial High School in Fresno.  Lena Costa is missed dearly, and while I know she was proud of the progress women made during her lifetime, I think she would be saddened to know there is still much more to do to ensure equality for all individuals.     #WomensHistoryMonth
Great to be at No Labels #FixNotFight Rally this morning! When Congress works together on a bipartisan basis, we can get things done.

The federal government must do everything it can to uncover the facts of Russia’s involvement in the 2016 election and prevent future attempts of foreign actors to undermine our democracy. Due to the uncertainty surrounding the actions of Attorney General Sessions I do not believe he can be viewed as objective in the Department of Justice’s investigation, and he should recuse himself immediately.

It's always great to be on CBS47 Fresno. This morning, I talked about the importance of Congress working together on a bipartisan basis and the need for Attorney General Sessions to recuse himself from the investigation into Russia's interference in our election.
Happy #ReadAcrossAmerica Day! It's important to read to young children & get kids excited about learning. Our nation's future depends on it.

Valley farmers are some of the best water conservationists.This week in the U.S. House Natural Resources Committee, I brought up the importance of focusing on sustainability as we work to modernize a broken water system in California.

The recent hate crimes against Indian Americans in Washington and Kansas cannot and will not be tolerated. Attacks on the Indian community are rooted in hatred, bigotry, and a complete lack of understanding of the faith and culture. My thoughts and prayers are with the victims, their families and all the Indian communities across the country.   The Central Valley is home to millions of individuals with different backgrounds, faiths, ethnicities, and cultures,  and I urge Valley residents to get know their neighbors, work colleagues, or store clerks - someone who looks, talks, dresses, or prays differently. Continued ignorance is only going to fuel hate. We must get to know one another, appreciate our differences, and remind ourselves that what unites us as Americans is far stronger than what divides us.

Congratulations to Andy Souza for receiving Feeding America’s Dick Goebel Public Service Award! Andy is the CEO and President of the Community Food Bank, and he is incredibly deserving of this national recognition. Each and every day, Andy works to make a difference in our Valley and helps to ensure that children and families do not go hungry. Every month, the Community Food Bank serves 280,000 San Joaquin Valley residents. We are fortunate to have Andy Souza as an advocate and champion for our San Joaquin Valley.

Congratulations to San Joaquin Valley resident, Amy Kitchener, for receiving a Congressional Appointment to serve on the Board of Trustees for the American Folklife Center at The Library of Congress! I know Amy will apply her strong Valley roots and decades of experience as she joins the Library of Congress in preserving our nation’s cultural diversity and rich traditions.  The San Joaquin Valley and entire state of California have a wealth of culture to share with the nation and world. Amy will proudly represent our state with great dedication.
Thank you to the women in the San Joaquin Valley and throughout the nation who make a difference everyday. When women succeed, America succeeds! #InternationalWomensDay #IWD2017

There are plenty of reasons why Congress and the Administration need to enact Comprehensive Immigration Reform. One of the reasons was brought up in today's House Agriculture Subcommittee hearing. We need immigration reform so that farmers, farm workers, and farming communities can be confident that the agriculture industry will have an adequate workforce to continue producing nutritious food to put on dinner tables throughout the nation and world.

Yesterday, I heard from San Joaquin Valley health care providers about what they think works in the Affordable Care Act and what in the law could be fixed. We also discussed the provisions in the recently introduced American Health Care Act. The fact is that since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, the uninsured rate among residents living in California’s 16th Congressional district has been cut in half from 22.5% to 11.1%. I understand the Affordable Care Act is not perfect. Republicans and Democrats in Congress and the Trump Administration must come together to fix the Affordable Care Act and implement health care policies that make sense for all Americans.

Brian Angus, thank you for stopping by the D.C. office, and thank you for your leadership at the Fresno Economic Opportunities Commission. You and your team make a positive difference in our Valley every single day.

Once again, a federal court blocked President Trump’s executive order to ban travel to United States and found the executive order to be discriminatory and potentially unconstitutional. Today, I spoke on the floor of the United States House of Representatives to reiterate the need for President Trump to work with the Congress on a bipartisan basis to fix our country’s broken immigration system.

Federal grants, like the Community Development Block Grant and TIGER Grant, are critical funding streams for our San Joaquin Valley, and President Trump wants to completely eliminate them. The President's budget blueprint would prove to have negative consequences for the majority of Americans, and in failing to address the main drivers of the federal debt, it is not a serious outline to putting our country on a path forward for fiscal sustainability.

Last week, I was on KSEE24 Central Valley Today and we talked about the legislative efforts to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA). In my district, the ACA has reduced the percentage of individuals who are uninsured from 22% to 11%. However, the ACA isn't perfect and provisions in the ACA need to be fixed. If we work together on a bipartisan basis, Congress can pass health care legislation that makes sense for all Americans.
Today is #NationalAgDay, but in the San Joaquin Valley, we know that every day is ag day. Please join me in thanking all of those who contribute to our nation's agriculture industry. #ThankaFarmer

It’s always an honor to receive the Spirit of Enterprise Award from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. I’m proud to advocate for legislation that supports businesses, creates jobs, and spurs economic growth.
Take cover and stay safe, Merced!

Tomorrow, the U.S. House of Representatives is expected to vote on the ACA repeal and replace legislation, the American Health Care Act (AHCA). I’m not going to be able to support the AHCA tomorrow because in its current form, the legislation would negatively impact hundreds of thousands of individuals in our San Joaquin Valley. I understand that the ACA needs to be fixed, and the only way we are going to be able find real solutions to fixing the ACA is by working together on a bipartisan basis.

This grant funding is much needed and will provide resources for clean-up efforts in communities throughout Merced County. I will continue to monitor the situation as more federal resources become available to assist California with flood impacts, and I’m working to ensure that counties located within the San Joaquin Valley receive our fair share of funding assistance to repair damaged roads and infrastructure.

This year is tracking to be the wettest year on record in California, but as a result of policies that inhibit the movement and storage of water through California’s broken water system, south of Delta agriculture water districts are receiving a 65 percent initial water allocation instead of their full contract amount. The delayed announcement, coupled with the partial water allocations in a year where California has been blessed with record rainfall is simply unacceptable.  I sincerely hope it is not an indication of what is to be expected in future years with average or below average rainfall.

The American Health Care Act (AHCA) was flawed policy and if it had been enacted in its current form, the law would have negatively impacted hundreds of thousands of San Joaquin Valley residents. For these reasons, I would have voted to oppose this measure.   Improvements need to be made to the Affordable Care Act but the AHCA was not the solution. The irresponsible cuts proposed by the AHCA would have caused hundreds of thousands of children, seniors, and women in the Valley to lose their health coverage. It is vital that we improve upon the gains we have made under the Affordable Care Act and make the necessary changes to improve coverage for all Americans.   I say it time and again, and I’ll keep saying it: the Congress and President are not going to fix America’s health care system without working together on a bipartisan basis. Today’s defeat of the American Health Care Act is a necessary step toward making real improvements to our health care system. I know how difficult it can be to stand up to your own party’s leadership and I commend my Republican colleagues who did so today. Moving forward, I encourage congressional Republicans and the Trump Administration to reach across the aisle to work with Democrats, including myself, who want to find real solutions to fixing provisions in the Affordable Care Act to improve health care outcomes for all Americans.

It was a pleasure to meet with Preston Prince and his team at the Fresno Housing Authority to hear about how they are working diligently to end homelessness, especially veteran homelessness, in our San Joaquin Valley.

The Heroine of the Month for March 2017 is Theresa Lopez from Madera, California. Theresa is a Veterans Service Representative for Madera County. Veterans and their families deserve the very best care and services, and Theresa works everyday to ensure that our Valley veterans receive the VA benefits they've earned.

The Community Health Centers in our San Joaquin Valley provide quality and affordable health care services to Valley residents. Thank you Camarena Health, Livingston Community Health, and Golden Valley Health Centers for all you do and for stopping by the D.C. office!
My office was proud to celebrate #ChildrensHospitalsWeek. We are grateful for the compassionate and hard working doctors, nurses, and staff at Valley Children's Hospital!

This morning, I joined in expressing strong support for the Temperance Flat Dam project. It completely defies logic to release water, which could be used for human, agricultural, or environmental use, out to the ocean, especially after five years of devastating drought conditions. The entire state of California needs its water infrastructure updated, and that includes building water storage projects, like Temperance Flat Dam. The future viability of the San Joaquin Valley is dependent upon a reliable water supply. Efforts to store water must be improved, both below and above ground, during wet years so water is available during the dry years.

Today's #EqualPayDay. Clearly, there's a lot more work to be done to close the gender pay gap. By enacting policies like the #PaycheckFairnessAct, we can ensure that women receive #equalpay for equal work.
April is Sexual Assault Awareness Month. Please join in using your voice to raise awareness so we can prevent and end sexual violence. #SexualAssaultAwarenessMonth #SAAM

It was an honor to present Danielle Quiroga with the Eva Murillo Unsung Hero Award from the Congressional Victims' Rights Caucus. Danielle is a survivor of a terrorism inspired incident that took place on November 4, 2015 on the UC Merced campus. She has experienced a devastating trauma, but Danielle's positive outlook on life has helped her, her family and witnesses of the horrific incident cope with the tragedy. Danielle is an inspiration for all of us, and it was truly an honor for her to be in Washington, D.C. to accept the award. #BobcatStrong

I joined my colleagues and Fresno State President, Dr. Joseph Castro, to commemorate the heroic and proud Armenian people who suffered greatly more than 100 years ago during the Armenian Genocide. Growing up in Fresno, my friends of Armenian descent have told me again and again about the horrors their parents and grandparents witnessed. They never forgot the tragedy, and neither will I, especially when silence is genocide’s best ally. Achieving peace today requires recognizing the dark parts of our history and moving forward to find a place of understanding and cooperation.  Fresno State is the only university campus in the nation that has a monument dedicated to recognizing the Armenian genocide. The circular stone structure is composed of nine pillars, each representing a region of historic Armenia and is topped by an incomplete steel halo symbolizing the disruption of Armenian history and the fracture caused by the genocide.

Judge Armando Rodriguez was a true American hero who devoted his entire life to serving others. As a son of immigrants, he knew the value of hard work and a quality education. He was a wonderful man from humble beginnings, and he successfully established a lifelong career as a public servant.  Judge Rodriguez was a good friend of mine.  He was also an inspiration and role model for so many throughout our community. His legacy will live on through the countless lives he’s impacted and the lasting contributions he’s made to our state’s judicial system, the arts, and education.

President Donald Trump’s decision to launch a limited missile strike in Syria was the correct action to take to send the message to President Bashar al-Assad that the use of chemical weapons will not be tolerated by the United States.  Assad’s horrific actions are not only attacks on his own people, but he is putting Western civilization and the entire world at risk.     The Trump Administration needs to come up with a comprehensive strategy to combat the Assad regime, and if the Authorization for Use of Military Force is necessary, then Congress must act.  I stand ready to work with my colleagues in Congress and President on this issue.

Last week, I joined the Madera community to celebrate the groundbreaking of Madera's first School Based Health Center. I applaud Camarena Health and Madera Unified School District for their commitment to ensuring that students and their families receive quality health care services.

On April 14th, the Vaisakhi Festival will be celebrated by Sikhs around the world, including thousands in California’s San Joaquin Valley and across the United States. I join in celebrating Vaisakhi with my Sikh friends and neighbors.

It’s been a decade since Valley farmers have received their full water allocation in the federal service area. Today’s announcement is long overdue, but it is very welcome news for farmers, farm workers, and communities in the San Joaquin Valley.  Agriculture is the backbone of our Valley’s economy, and this much needed water will allow farmers to plant the healthy and nutritious crops that feed our nation and world.   While I applaud today’s announcement, there is no denying that California’s water system is broken, and further action must be taken to move California’s water system into the 21st century. Investments need to be made to build water storage and fix broken water infrastructure, so that more water can be captured during years with above average rain and snow fall. Additionally, the current policies that operate California’s water system are flawed and must be modified. Water that could be stored or used to recharge groundwater aquifers that have been depleted because of the drought is flowing out to the ocean. The status quo not only defies logic but is simply not sustainable.

Funding the government so it can fulfill its promises to the American people is one of Congress’s most basic responsibilities. The legislation Congress passed today is a bipartisan compromise that provides vital funding for water and transportation infrastructure, veterans services, education, and community safety through the end of September 2017. This funding creates more certainty for our Valley’s families and business owners, diversifies California’s water supply, increases public safety and provides more opportunities to plan for the near-term future. However, this legislation is not a long-term solution to put our country on a more sustainable fiscal path. It’s been over four years since Congress has passed a bill directing longer-term spending, which creates uncertainty for families and businesses and impacts their ability to plan for the future. Congress cannot continue this irresponsible governance. We must come together and have bipartisan negotiations to pass a long-term budget bill later this year.

This Saturday, June 17th is our nation-wide call to action for the 8.8 million legal permanent residents in the United States who are eligible to become U.S. citizens to begin taking the steps necessary for naturalization.   The significance of American citizenship cannot be understated. Becoming a U.S. citizen can be a monumental event in an immigrant’s life, and it is often a key part in their journey towards achieving the American Dream. As individuals take their citizenship oath across our country, they are sometimes completing a plan that has been generations in the making. Surrounded by loved ones, these new U.S. citizens are beginning their American story.   With their new citizenship, these individuals also gain the immense responsibility and numerous benefits that accompany U.S. citizenship. As we draw closer to our Citizenship Day of Action on Saturday, June 17th, I will highlight specific responsibilities and benefits of American citizenship every day.     If you have questions or would like help with the process of becoming a U.S. citizen, contact our Fresno office at 559-495-1620, our Merced office at 209-384-1620, or visit the federal government’s informational website here: https://www.uscis.gov/

Responsibility and Benefit of Being an American Citizen #1:  Support and defend the U.S. Constitution and the laws of the United States, and pledge allegiance to the United States.   Immigrants and new U.S. citizens are often highly patriotic members of our communities, and naturalized citizens serve in our armed forces, our National Guard units, and our police forces. Last week I joined Representative Ted Poe (R-TX), my colleague and fellow Co-Chairman of the Victims’ Rights Caucus, to introduce Jane’s Law (H.R. 2829) in the House of Representatives.   This bipartisan legislation, which I am proud to cosponsor, will close the loophole that currently allows ex-spouses to cross state lines in order to avoid paying court-ordered distributions. Sadly, this practice can lead to years of financial hardship for the spouse and children left behind because these court-ordered payments are not enforceable over state lines.   It is time to put an end to this practice and make sure our laws are followed. Jane’s Law is an important step in closing loopholes that allow offenders to evade justice.

Responsibility and Benefit of Being an American Citizen #2:  Respect and embrace the different opinions, cultures, ethnic groups, races, and religions which weave together to form the strong fabric of our nation.   Americans are not united by a common race, religion, or ethnicity, but by our shared American values.

We must continue to come together to support Alzheimer’s research, like we did in Merced on Saturday, and like we did in the House of Representatives in April when we called for additional funding for Alzheimer’s research at the National Institutes of Health.  I will continue to advocate for additional Alzheimer's research because only by standing together can we beat this disease. And we must win this fight.

Today, I spoke in the U.S. House of Representatives about just how critical America's credibility is to our national security.  To remain credible, the United States cannot change positions on international agreements from one administration to another, without serious justification and the consent of our allies.  Especially now, as we are facing an increasing threat in North Korea, we must stand with our allies and work together to make a safer world through a comprehensive strategy of diplomacy, sanctions, and deterrence.  I will continue to advocate for strong, steady, and comprehensive national security strategies, and I invite my colleagues from both sides of the aisle to join me in working towards making our world safer and our country more secure.

Our forest managers, as hard as they have tried, simply cannot do their jobs effectively as long as congressional budget rules cause this never ending cycle of "fire-borrowing." "Fire-borrowing" is when an organization in charge of our forests is forced to use money intended for forest management practices -- many of which would prevent wildfires --  to fight fires because costs for fighting the fires are more than the organization has budgeted.  For years I have advocated for reform that will end this broken cycle, including cosponsoring the Wildfire Disaster Funding Act and calling on the Administration and members of Congress to fund fighting wildfires like we do other natural disasters.  Congress and the Administration need to come together on this issue, and I stand ready to work with my colleagues and the Administration in order to help protect the American people.  #CAFires #CaliforniaWildfires

It has been over four months since the Administration announced it would terminate the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (#DACA) program. Since then, there has been an outpouring of support for #DREAMers, and a large majority of Americans want to #ProtectDREAMers. Many of us came together – members of Congress, state and local government officials, and countless national and community organizations – to call for the protection of these young people who were brought to the United States as children.  As I have been saying for years, we must fix our broken immigration system with bipartisan comprehensive immigration reform. America needs commonsense, just, and stable immigration policy. The piecemeal, fleeting, and often contradictory measures we currently have are a large part of the reason nearly 800,000 DREAMers are under threat of being forced out of the only country they have ever called home. This is irresponsible governance. It is indefensible, and it must end.  We must continue to stand with DREAMers, and we must continue to work for the bipartisan comprehensive immigration reform America so badly needs. I urge my fellow members of Congress – from both sides of the aisle – to join me.  #WeStandWithDreamers #ComprehensiveImmigrationReform #BipartisanSolutions

Yesterday I was joined by Vietnam veteran Congressman Paul Cook in introducing the Hmong Veterans’ Service Recognition Act into the House of Representatives. The bipartisan legislation would extend to Hmong and Lao Americans who served alongside U.S. Armed Forces during the Vietnam War burial benefits in national cemeteries.  Hmong forces saved countless American lives during the Vietnam War, and more than 100,000 Hmong made the ultimate sacrifice over the course of the war. These heroes deserve our nation’s deep gratitude, and granting Hmong veterans the honor of being laid to rest in our national cemeteries, such as the San Joaquin Valley National Cemetery, is long overdue.  In addition to having bipartisan support in both chambers of Congress, the legislation is supported by the national and #SanJoaquin Valley chapters of the Special Guerrilla Unit Veterans and Families Development of USA, Inc and the Lao Veterans of America.   #Hmong #HmongVeterans #AmericanHeroes  For more information: https://costa.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/costa-introduces-bipartisan-legislation-honor-hmong-veterans
